title: M1: Workflow spec + CLI (non-exec)
body:
Goal: define workflow file format + CLI surface without execution.

Deliverables:
- .forge/workflows location + naming conventions documented.
- Workflow schema doc (types, fields, stop conditions).
- CLI: workflow ls/show/validate (no run).

Acceptance:
- Can parse + validate example workflow file.
- Helpful errors on missing/invalid fields.
- CLI commands return non-zero on invalid files.

Tests:
- Unit tests for parser/validator.
- CLI tests for ls/show/validate.

title: M2: Workflow runner (sequential, minimal steps)
body:
Goal: execute workflows sequentially with minimal step types.

Scope:
- Step types: agent, bash, loop.
- Sequential DAG execution (topo order), no fan-out.
- Basic run log + step status persisted.

Acceptance:
- forge workflow run executes a simple workflow end-to-end.
- Step failures stop workflow with clear error.
- Logs show per-step start/stop + duration.

Tests:
- Unit tests for DAG order.
- Integration test: run sample workflow with bash steps.

title: M3: Stop conditions, inputs/outputs, hooks, fan-out
body:
Goal: add richer workflow semantics without triggers or mesh.

Scope:
- Stop conditions (expr/tool/loop count).
- Step inputs/outputs binding.
- Pre/post hooks on steps + workflow.
- Fan-out with fixed concurrency limit.

Acceptance:
- Stop conditions can end loops deterministically.
- Outputs flow into downstream step inputs.
- Hooks run and are logged.
- Fan-out executes in parallel with bounded concurrency.

Tests:
- Unit tests for stop evaluation + IO binding.
- Integration test for fan-out execution order.

title: M4: Human-in-loop steps + approvals
body:
Goal: allow workflows to block on human approval.

Scope:
- Step type: human (prompt + timeout).
- Approval storage + CLI to approve/deny.
- Workflow status shows blocked + reason.

Acceptance:
- Workflow pauses at human step and resumes on approval.
- Timeout handling documented and tested.
- CLI surface for approvals documented.

Tests:
- Integration test with manual approval flow.
- Unit tests for approval state transitions.

title: M5: Jobs + triggers (cron/webhook)
body:
Goal: job layer that starts workflows via triggers.

Scope:
- Job definitions + persistence.
- Trigger types: cron + webhook.
- Job run history + logs.

Acceptance:
- Can register job and trigger it by cron or webhook.
- Job run emits logs and status.
- CLI to list/show/rerun jobs.

Tests:
- Unit tests for trigger parsing.
- Integration test: cron trigger fires a workflow.

title: M6: Nodes + mesh routing
body:
Goal: multi-node orchestration with master routing.

Scope:
- forged daemon: register node + accept commands.
- Mesh registry + master selection.
- Remote execution of workflow/loop commands.

Acceptance:
- Can register a node and run workflow remotely.
- Master failover documented (even if manual).
- Security: bearer token enforced for remote calls.

Tests:
- Integration test with local loopback daemon.
- Unit tests for routing decisions.

title: M1.1: Workflow schema doc + example
body:
Scope:
- New doc (docs/workflows.md) describing TOML fields.
- Example workflow file in .forge/workflows.
- Update quickstart or README with workflow mention.

Acceptance:
- Docs explain step types + stop conditions.
- Example validates with parser.

title: M1.2: Workflow loader + validator
body:
Scope:
- Parse .forge/workflows/*.toml.
- Validate required fields, unique step ids, DAG integrity.
- Return structured errors (path + line where possible).

Acceptance:
- Invalid file returns clear validation errors.
- Valid file returns normalized workflow struct.

Tests:
- Unit tests for schema validation.
- Fixture tests for invalid cases.

title: M1.3: CLI workflow ls/show/validate
body:
Scope:
- forge workflow ls/show/validate commands.
- Use loader + validator.
- JSON output support.

Acceptance:
- ls shows available workflow names.
- show prints normalized workflow.
- validate exits non-zero on error.

Tests:
- CLI tests for each command.

title: M1.4: Workflow fixtures + validation tests
body:
Scope:
- Add fixture workflows (valid + invalid).
- Golden output for show/validate.
- Keep fixtures small and documented.

Acceptance:
- Tests cover common error cases.
- Fixtures used by CLI tests.

title: M2.1: Workflow engine (sequential DAG)
body:
Scope:
- Build workflow execution engine with topo sort.
- Track step state (pending/running/success/failed).
- Persist run metadata (id, timestamps, errors).

Acceptance:
- Deterministic step order for simple DAG.
- Failure stops downstream steps.

Tests:
- Unit tests for topo ordering + failure propagation.

title: M2.2: Step executors (agent|bash|loop)
body:
Scope:
- Agent step uses existing harness execution path.
- Bash step runs command in repo workdir.
- Loop step reuses current loop runner (single loop instance).

Acceptance:
- Agent + bash + loop steps work in same workflow.
- Step logs captured in workflow run output.

Tests:
- Integration test using bash + loop steps.

title: M2.3: CLI workflow run + logs
body:
Scope:
- forge workflow run <name>.
- Emit run id + status.
- Persist run logs (per-step).

Acceptance:
- run command executes sequential workflow.
- logs command shows per-step output.

Tests:
- CLI integration test for run/logs.

title: M2.4: Workflow ledger entries
body:
Scope:
- Extend ledger format for workflow runs.
- Include step summaries + durations.
- Keep loop ledger unchanged for now.

Acceptance:
- Workflow run writes ledger entry per step.
- Ledger links to run id.

Tests:
- Unit test for ledger writer.

title: M3.1: Stop conditions evaluator
body:
Scope:
- Implement stop condition evaluation (expr + tool call).
- Integrate with loop step to stop on condition.
- Clear error on unsupported conditions.

Acceptance:
- stop.expr supports basic comparisons (count/tasks/open).
- stop.tool runs command and checks exit or output.

Tests:
- Unit tests for expr parsing + tool runner.

title: M3.2: Inputs/outputs binding
body:
Scope:
- Define input/output mapping in workflow structs.
- Resolve outputs into downstream inputs.
- Support simple templating (e.g., {{steps.id.output}}).

Acceptance:
- Downstream step receives upstream outputs.
- Missing output yields clear error.

Tests:
- Unit tests for binding + error cases.

title: M3.3: Step/workflow hooks
body:
Scope:
- Pre/post hooks on workflow + step.
- Hook types: bash initially.
- Hook failures configurable (fail|warn).

Acceptance:
- Hooks run in order and log output.
- Fail mode stops workflow.

Tests:
- Integration test with pre/post hooks.

title: M3.4: Fan-out execution + concurrency
body:
Scope:
- Allow steps to run in parallel when deps satisfied.
- Add concurrency limit config.
- Track per-step progress for fan-out.

Acceptance:
- Parallel steps run concurrently up to limit.
- Order respects dependencies.

Tests:
- Integration test with 3 parallel bash steps.

title: M4.1: Human step model + persistence
body:
Scope:
- Add human step type fields (prompt, timeout).
- Persist approval state + timestamps.
- Default timeout behavior documented.

Acceptance:
- Workflow pauses at human step.
- State survives process restart.

Tests:
- Unit tests for human step state transitions.

title: M4.2: CLI approvals
body:
Scope:
- forge workflow approve/deny <run> <step>.
- List blocked steps for a run.

Acceptance:
- Approve resumes workflow.
- Deny stops workflow with reason.

Tests:
- Integration test for approve path.

title: M4.3: Blocked status in workflow show
body:
Scope:
- show command displays blocked steps + reason.
- Include timeout info.

Acceptance:
- Operators can see where to approve.

Tests:
- CLI test for blocked output.

title: M5.1: Job model + persistence
body:
Scope:
- Define job config format.
- Persist job runs (status, inputs, outputs).

Acceptance:
- Jobs can be created + listed.
- Run history stored and retrievable.

Tests:
- Unit tests for job store.

title: M5.2: Trigger scheduler (cron)
body:
Scope:
- Cron parser + scheduler loop.
- Trigger storage + next fire time.

Acceptance:
- Cron triggers start jobs.
- Misconfigured cron rejected.

Tests:
- Unit tests for cron parsing.

title: M5.3: Webhook trigger endpoint
body:
Scope:
- HTTP endpoint to trigger job by name.
- Auth with bearer token.

Acceptance:
- Webhook hits start job + logs run.
- Unauthorized requests rejected.

Tests:
- Integration test with local HTTP server.

title: M5.4: CLI job/trigger commands
body:
Scope:
- forge job ls/show/run/logs/cancel.
- forge trigger add/ls/rm.

Acceptance:
- CLI commands work end-to-end.

Tests:
- CLI tests for job + trigger flows.

title: M6.1: forged node daemon + registration
body:
Scope:
- forged API for exec + status.
- Node registration + auth token.

Acceptance:
- Local forged accepts a loop/workflow command.

Tests:
- Integration test for daemon API.

title: M6.2: Mesh registry + master selection
body:
Scope:
- Mesh config storage.
- Promote/demote master (manual).

Acceptance:
- Mesh status shows active master.

Tests:
- Unit tests for registry + selection.

title: M6.3: Remote routing for workflow/loop
body:
Scope:
- Route commands to master -> node.
- Error handling when node offline.

Acceptance:
- forge node exec runs on remote.
- forge workflow run --node works.

Tests:
- Integration test with local + simulated node.

title: M1.2a: Workflow loader
body:

- Load .forge/workflows/*.toml.

- Return raw parsed model.

Acceptance:
- Loader returns TOML parse errors with file path.

title: M1.2b: Workflow validator (schema + DAG)

title: M1.3c: CLI workflow validate
body:

title: M2.2c: Loop step executor

title: M2.3a: CLI workflow run
body:
Scope:
- forge workflow run <name>.

title: M2.3b: CLI workflow logs

title: M2.3c: Workflow run persistence
body:
Scope:

Acceptance:

title: M3.1a: Stop expr parser/eval
body:
Scope:
- Minimal expression language for stop conditions.

Acceptance:

title: M3.1b: Stop tool runner
body:
Scope:
- Run tool/command for stop condition.

Acceptance:

title: M3.1c: Loop stop integration
body:
Scope:
- Apply stop conditions in loop step executor.

Acceptance:

title: M3.4a: Parallel scheduler core
body:
Scope:

- Respect dependencies + step limits.

Acceptance:

title: M3.4b: Concurrency config
body:
Scope:

title: M3.4c: Fan-out status display
body:
Scope:
- Report per-step running/queued counts.

title: M5.3a: Webhook server wiring
body:
Scope:

- Route /hooks/<name> to job runner.

title: M5.3b: Webhook auth

title: M7: Teams + task delegation
body:
Goal: persistent teams of agents with task delegation rules.

Scope:
- Team + member + role model.
- Task inbox + assignment lifecycle.
- Delegation rules engine.
- CLI/TUI surfaces for teams + tasks.
- Agent messaging integration (fmail).

Acceptance:
- Can create team, add members, send task to team.
- Task routed to an agent using rules.
- Team/task status visible in CLI.

Tests:
- Unit tests for model + delegation.
- CLI tests for team/task flows.

title: M7.1: Team model + persistence
body:
Scope:
- Define Team, TeamMember, TeamRole (leader|member) structs.
- Persist teams + members (migrations + repo).
- Team config (delegation rules, default assignee, heartbeat interval).
- TeamService CRUD APIs.

Acceptance:
- Create/list/show/delete team works.
- Members + roles stored and retrievable.
- Team config validated on write.

Tests:
- Unit tests for model validation.
- Repo tests for create/list/load/delete.

title: M7.2: Team task inbox + assignment lifecycle
body:
Scope:
- Task model (id, team_id, payload json, status, assigned_agent_id, timestamps).
- Statuses: queued|assigned|running|blocked|done|failed|canceled.
- FIFO ordering + explicit priority field.
- TaskService APIs: submit, assign, reassign, complete, fail.

Acceptance:
- Can submit task to team and list queue.
- Assign/reassign updates status + audit trail.
- Task state persists across restarts.

Tests:
- Unit tests for state transitions.
- Repo tests for task ordering + filters.

title: M7.3: Delegation rules engine
body:
Scope:
- Rule schema (match on payload.type, tags, repo, priority).
- Rule evaluation order + fallbacks (leader/default).
- Deterministic routing + explain output.
- Config stored per team.

Acceptance:
- Given a task payload, engine returns target agent.
- Rule conflicts resolved deterministically.
- CLI can show why a task was routed.

Tests:
- Unit tests for rule parsing + evaluation.
- Golden tests for explain output.

title: M7.4: CLI/TUI for teams + tasks

Scope:

- CLI: forge team member add/rm/ls.

- TUI views: teams list + task inbox (read-only ok v1).

Acceptance:

- CLI shows task status + assignee.

Tests:
- CLI integration tests for team/task flows.

title: M7.5: fmail integration for team messaging

- Configure fmail agent name + topics per team/agent.

Acceptance:

Tests:

title: M8: Agent profiles + prompt registry/autodetection

Goal: first-class agent + prompt definitions with autodetection.

Scope:

- Autodetection rules for selecting prompts/profiles.
- CLI surfaces for list/show/validate.

Acceptance:
- Repo can define agents + prompts and reference by id.
- Autodetection selects prompt/profile deterministically.
- CLI shows registry contents.

Tests:
- Unit tests for parsing + rule evaluation.
- CLI tests for list/show/validate.

title: M10: Improve TUI
body: Improve the TUI for better user experience.

title: TUI: Implement two-pane layout and mode framework
body:
Implement the base two-pane layout for forge tui (left loop list + right detail pane) and introduce explicit UI modes: Main, Filter, Expanded Logs, Confirm.

Scope:
- Replace current 2x2 card rendering with split-pane renderer.
- Add mode state machine and key-precedence handling (sub-mode exit with q/esc; Main retains existing quit behavior).
- Ensure refresh loop and rendering are stable during mode transitions.

Done when:
- forge tui launches into two-pane layout.
- mode transitions are deterministic and test-covered.

title: TUI: Build left loop list with STATUS/ID/RUNS/DIR columns
body:
Implement left-pane list rendering backed by the same loop/state semantics as forge ps.

Scope:
- Columns: STATUS, ID, RUNS, DIR (basename(repo_path)).
- Include stopped loops by default with visible stopped state.
- Default sort oldest-created first.
- Preserve selection across refresh; if selected loop disappears select nearest surviving row.
- Keep keyboard navigation: j/k and ArrowUp/ArrowDown.

Done when:
- list matches PRD column and inclusion rules.
- selection behavior is stable and covered by tests.

title: TUI: Implement right detail pane and adaptive log tail
body:
Implement right-pane detail rendering for selected loop and conditional bottom log-tail window.

Scope:
- Show id, name, status, runs, full working dir, pool/profile, last run timestamp, queue depth, interval/max-runtime/max-iterations when present.
- When vertical space allows, render log tail sub-window with fallback text for missing/empty logs.
- Keep right pane synchronized with left-pane selection changes.

Done when:
- detail fields update on selection change and refresh.
- log-tail window appears/disappears based on available height without layout breakage.

title: TUI: Add expanded log mode (l) with q/esc return
body:
Implement expanded log mode from PRD.

Scope:
- Key l enters Expanded Logs mode for selected loop.
- Expanded mode fills the entire right pane with live-follow log output.
- q or esc exits Expanded Logs and returns to Main mode layout.
- Preserve current loop selection while entering/exiting mode.

Done when:
- user can toggle expanded logs reliably and return without losing context.

title: TUI: Wire loop action shortcuts and async action feedback
body:
Implement per-selection shortcuts with responsive action execution.

Scope:
- Support shortcuts: S (stop), K (kill), D (delete), r (resume), l (expanded logs), n (new loop wizard).
- Trigger existing loop command semantics through internal control paths.
- Show transient success/failure status line after each action.
- Keep UI responsive while actions are in flight.

Done when:
- all listed shortcuts execute against selected loop and provide user feedback.

title: TUI: Implement destructive confirmation flows (S/K/D)
body:
Implement explicit destructive confirmation behavior from PRD.

Scope:
- Confirmation dialog required for S, K, D using [y/N] default No.
- q/esc cancel confirmation and return to Main mode.
- Exact confirmation copy:
  - S: Stop loop <id> after current iteration? [y/N]
  - K: Kill loop <id> immediately? [y/N]
  - D stopped: Delete loop record <id>? [y/N]
  - D running: Loop is still running. Force delete record <id>? [y/N]
- For D: detect loop running/non-stopped state and branch to force-delete prompt.

Done when:
- destructive actions cannot run without explicit confirmation and prompt text matches PRD.

title: TUI: Implement filter mode (/) with status selector
body:
Add interactive filter mode to loop list.

Scope:
- / enters Filter mode.
- Free-text filter matches name, id, and working directory path.
- tab cycles focus to status filter selector.
- Status selector options: all, running, waiting, stopped, error (plus any additional surfaced states).
- Filter updates results in real time.
- esc exits Filter mode to Main; clearing filter restores full list.

Done when:
- users can quickly narrow loop list by text and status without leaving TUI.

title: TUI: Build new-loop wizard (n) with forge up parity
body:
Implement in-TUI new-loop wizard for n shortcut.

Scope:
- Step flow: (1) identity/count (2) pool/profile assignment (3) prompt/runtime options (4) review+submit.
- Fields: name or name-prefix, count, pool/profile (mutually exclusive), prompt, prompt-msg, interval, max-runtime, max-iterations, tags.
- Reuse existing forge up validation and defaults where possible.
- On submit success: create loop(s), refresh list, select newly created loop.
- On submit failure: show inline error and keep wizard open for correction.

Done when:
- wizard can create valid loops without leaving TUI and handles invalid input gracefully.

title: TUI: Apply PRD status colors, borders, and focus styling
body:
Implement the visual design guidance in the PRD for status semantics and pane emphasis.

Scope:
- Status colors: running #22C55E, waiting #F59E0B, stopped #6B7280, error #EF4444, paused #3B82F6 (if surfaced).
- Border guidance: left #334155, right #0EA5E9 accent, selected row bg #1E293B fg #E2E8F0 outline #38BDF8.
- Confirmation dialog styling: warning border #F97316 and destructive label #EF4444.
- Ensure status text remains visible (not color-only).

Done when:
- colors/styles are consistently applied and readable in common terminal themes.

title: TUI: Add automated tests for PRD interaction and action rules
body:
Add/extend automated tests covering key PRD behavior for improved TUI.

Scope:
- Navigation tests for j/k and arrow keys with stable selection semantics.
- Mode transition tests: Main <-> Filter <-> Expanded Logs <-> Confirm.
- Destructive confirmation tests for S/K/D, including running-loop force-delete prompt.
- Filter behavior tests for text fields and status selector with tab.
- Expanded logs entry/exit tests (l then q/esc).
- Wizard flow tests for validation and successful loop creation path.

Done when:
- test suite captures acceptance-criteria behavior and protects against regressions.

title: TUI: Cover acceptance criterion 11 (empty/error states) with tests
body:
Map AC11 from PRD_TUI.md into explicit tests.

Scope:
- Assert empty-state messaging explains how to start a loop.
- Assert error rendering path is resilient and visible.
- Keep tests focused on non-crash behavior and operator guidance text.

Done when:
- internal/looptui tests cover AC11 expectations.

title: TUI: Cover acceptance criterion 12 with non-TUI loop command regression tests
body:
Map AC12 from PRD_TUI.md into explicit regression checks.

Scope:
- Add tests for existing non-TUI loop command paths (stop/kill/resume and record deletion behavior) to ensure TUI changes did not alter semantics.
- Keep tests command/repository level and deterministic.

Done when:
- test suite includes focused regression checks and passes.

title: Epic: Forge TUI 1% UX Excellence
body: Unify and ship a top-percentile Forge TUI experience. Scope: navigation speed, observability depth, matrix usability, performance, accessibility, and incident replay.

body: Add fuzzy command palette for jumping loops/runs/tabs/actions. Include keyboard-only flow and contextual actions.

title: TUI: Universal search across logs/runs/metadata
body: Implement full-text search mode spanning live logs, run output, loop metadata. Add highlight + next/prev matches.

title: TUI: Time scrubber for loop timeline
body: Add timeline scrubber to traverse historical runs/log windows by time with keyboard controls.

title: TUI: Multi-view paging for matrix panels
body: In view 4, page through loop sets beyond visible capacity. Preserve pinned-first ordering and show page indicators.

title: TUI: Pane focus and side-by-side compare

title: TUI: Semantic log layers
body: Add toggles for raw/events/errors/tools/diff views. Keep harness-aware highlighting per layer.

title: TUI: Alert rail for failures/stuck loops
body: Add sticky alert strip for failures, stuck loops, queue growth. Quick-jump to affected loop.

title: TUI: Activity heatmap and sparklines
body: Add compact trend visuals for run rate, error rate, and duration/latency per loop.

title: TUI: Session bookmarks
body: Allow bookmarking runs/log lines and jumping across bookmarks. Persist during TUI session.

title: TUI: Contextual onboarding and key hints
body: Improve in-tab hints and first-run guidance overlays with dismiss/recall behavior.

title: TUI: Keyboard macros
body: Record and replay common navigation/filter/layout sequences.

title: TUI: Performance mode and incremental rendering
body: Optimize refresh cadence and rendering for high loop counts; avoid full redraw hot paths.

title: TUI: Theme packs and accessibility presets
body: Add high-contrast/low-light/colorblind-safe presets with quick switching.

title: TUI: Incident replay mode
body: Capture and replay TUI state/events over time for incident reconstruction.

Started command palette implementation planning in looptui model/events/render paths.

title: M10: Persistent subagent sessions (non-loop delegation)
body:
Goal:
- Add first-class persistent subagent sessions for non-loop workflows.
- Parent agent can spawn child, send one-off work, then continue chatting with same child on demand.
- Keep sessions alive between tasks; support revive/resume when possible.

Problem:
- Current loop-first UX good for continuous repo loops, poor fit for ad-hoc delegated one-off + re-engage workflow.
- Existing forged RPC has spawn/send primitives, but no stable end-user session primitive in forge CLI.

Scope:
- New session lifecycle primitive (spawn/send/wait/list/interrupt/kill/revive).
- Explicit harness capability handling (interactive vs one-shot modes).
- Parent-focused delegation helper command for low-friction use.
- Persistence, observability, safety policies, docs.

Out of scope:
- Replacing loop runtime.
- Full autonomous team routing system (covered by M7+).

Success metrics:
- Parent can re-use same child session across multiple delegated tasks in one day.
- Median command count for delegated task <= 3 commands.
- Failed delegation due to dead/non-interactive session reduced via capability checks and revive path.

Acceptance:
- CLI session flow works end-to-end locally and with forged daemon.
- Harness mismatch errors are explicit/actionable.
- Session state is inspectable and auditable.

title: M10.1: Session model + lifecycle state machine
body:
Scope:
- Define canonical Session model: id, parent_session_id/parent_agent_id, workspace/repo, node, harness, mode, state, created_at, last_activity_at, ttl, labels/tags.
- Define state machine: starting -> idle/working/awaiting_approval -> idle ... -> stopped/error/expired.
- Define transitions + invariants (e.g. send only when session exists; revive only from stopped/error/expired).
- Define mapping between forged AgentState and new SessionState.
- Define contract for "continuous" vs "one-shot" sessions.

Deliverables:
- Design doc in docs/design/session-subagents.md
- State diagram + transition table.
- Error taxonomy (not_found, not_interactive, dead_session, transport_unavailable, timeout_waiting_idle, policy_denied).

Acceptance:
- All session commands reference same state definitions.
- No ambiguous transitions.
- Edge cases documented: daemon restart, pane missing, process exit, approval wait.

Tests:
- Unit tests for transition validator.

title: M10.2: Session persistence (DB schema + repos)
body:
Scope:
- Add DB schema for persistent sessions + session events/messages.
- Suggested tables:
  - sessions
  - session_messages (outbound/inbound metadata)
  - session_events (state transitions, control actions)
- Add repositories for CRUD/list/filter and append-only event writes.
- Add indexes for hot paths: by state, by parent, by updated_at, by workspace.
- Add migration rollback safety.

Acceptance:
- Session survives process restart.
- Listing by workspace/parent/state efficient.
- Event history queryable for audit/explain.

Tests:
- Migration tests up/down.
- Repository tests for create/get/list/filter/pagination.

title: M10.3: Session service on top of forged transport
body:
Scope:
- Implement forged-backed session service APIs using existing SpawnAgent/SendInput/List/Get/Kill primitives.
- Add abstraction so session ops can run local or daemon-backed consistently.
- Implement operations: SpawnSession, SendMessage, WaitState, InterruptSession, KillSession, ListSessions, GetSession.
- Store each operation in session_events.
- Normalize transport errors.

Acceptance:
- Service can manage multiple concurrent sessions.
- WaitState works for idle/working/approval/stopped with timeout.
- Failures emit structured events and retain debug context.

Tests:
- Unit tests with mocked forged client.
- Integration test with local forged daemon for spawn/send/wait/kill.

title: M10.4: CLI surface for forge session commands
body:
Scope:
- Add CLI group: forge session.
- Subcommands:
  - forge session spawn
  - forge session send
  - forge session wait
  - forge session ps
  - forge session show
  - forge session interrupt
  - forge session kill
  - forge session revive
- Add JSON output contracts for automation.
- Add context-aware defaults (workspace, last session, parent marker) without hidden magic.

Acceptance:
- Non-interactive automation works with --json.
- Human UX concise and predictable.
- Errors provide next-step hints.

Tests:
- CLI tests for parse/validation.
- Golden tests for JSON output envelopes.

title: M10.5: Parent-oriented forge subagent run helper
body:
Scope:
- Add high-level parent-helper command:
  - forge subagent run "task" [--session <id>] [--type codex] [--wait idle] [--revive]
- Behavior:
  - if session exists: reuse.
  - else spawn with requested/default profile.
  - send task.
  - optionally wait for idle/completion marker.
  - return summary payload for parent automation.
- Include ergonomic flags for label/tag/task-id correlation.

Acceptance:
- One command handles common delegation loop.
- Re-run with same --session continues prior callee context.
- Output includes session_id + observed state + quick tail.

Tests:
- Integration tests for create/reuse/revive paths.

title: M10.6: Harness capability matrix + mode guardrails
body:
Scope:
- Implement harness capability registry:
  - supports_interactive_session
  - supports_reliable_idle_detection
  - supports_approval_signal
  - default_command_mode (interactive vs one-shot)
- Add guardrails:
  - reject continuous-session requests for one-shot command modes.
  - suggest fix (e.g., use interactive codex command, not codex exec).
- Expose capability info in session show/doctor output.

Acceptance:
- User cannot accidentally create "continuous" session on one-shot mode without explicit override.
- Messages clearly explain mismatch.

Tests:
- Unit tests for capability lookup and guards.

title: M10.7: Wait semantics and state synchronization
body:
Scope:
- Implement robust wait semantics:
  - wait for idle
  - wait for approval-needed
  - wait for stopped/error
  - timeout/cancel support
- Add event-stream + polling fallback strategy.
- Add --until and --timeout controls in CLI.

Acceptance:
- Wait command deterministic; no busy-looping.
- Timeout exits with typed error and last observed state.

Tests:
- Unit tests with simulated state streams.
- Integration tests with delayed transitions.

title: M10.8: Session revive/resume workflow
body:
Scope:
- Implement revive workflow:
  - detect dead session (pane/process missing).
  - respawn compatible session.
  - inject revive preamble containing compact context (last task, summary, pending objective).
- Add revive policy flags:
  - never
  - ask
  - auto
- Ensure revive preserves parent linkage and audit trail.

Acceptance:
- Revive success path transparent to caller.
- Revive failure returns actionable remediation.

Tests:
- Integration tests for dead-session detection + respawn.

title: M10.9: TTL, idle expiry, and session GC
body:
Scope:
- Add lifecycle controls for parked sessions:
  - ttl
  - idle timeout
  - optional max age
- Add GC worker/command to terminate expired sessions safely.
- Emit events before/after eviction.

Acceptance:
- Stale sessions do not accumulate indefinitely.
- Active sessions not evicted prematurely.

Tests:
- Unit tests for TTL evaluator.
- Integration test for GC path.

title: M10.10: Approval/policy inheritance and redaction
body:
Scope:
- Propagate approval policy + account/profile context from parent to child spawn defaults.
- Add policy checks for risky send/interrupt commands.
- Add redaction rules for sensitive payloads in session events.

Acceptance:
- Child runs with expected approval posture.
- Sensitive text not leaked in audit fields.

Tests:
- Unit tests for policy inheritance + redaction.

title: M10.11: Session summaries for parent rehydration
body:
Scope:
- Add transcript summarization helper for parent agents:
  - concise status
  - latest task outcome
  - unresolved blockers
- Store summary snapshots in session_events or dedicated summary table.
- Add CLI: forge session summary <id>.

Acceptance:
- Parent can quickly rehydrate child context without full log dump.
- Summary generation bounded/performant.

Tests:
- Unit tests for summarizer formatting.

title: M10.12: End-to-end and regression test matrix
body:
Scope:
- Build comprehensive test matrix:
  - spawn/send/wait/interrupt/kill/revive
  - capability mismatch paths
  - daemon unavailable fallback errors
  - multi-session concurrency
- Add regression tests for known pitfalls:
  - one-shot harness used as continuous session
  - stale pane ID after restart

Acceptance:
- CI includes session flow tests with stable fixtures.
- Failures isolate root cause quickly.

title: M10.13: Docs and troubleshooting for delegated sessions
body:
Scope:
- Docs updates:
  - README section for session/subagent workflows.
  - docs/cli.md session commands + examples.
  - docs/quickstart.md delegation recipe.
  - docs/troubleshooting.md session failure playbook.
- Add explicit harness-mode guidance (interactive vs one-shot).

Acceptance:
- New user can run delegated continuous session flow in <10 min.
- Docs include at least 3 real command recipes.

title: M10.14: Session observability + explain support
body:
Scope:
- Add observability:
  - counters: sessions_spawned, sessions_revived, sends, interrupts, kill, wait_timeout
  - gauges: active_sessions, idle_sessions
  - latency: send_to_idle_duration
- Add explain integration for session IDs.

Acceptance:
- Operators can answer: what sessions exist, which are stale, where failures happen.
- Metrics emitted for both success and failure paths.

Tests:
- Unit tests for metric emission hooks.

- No ambiguous transitions.
- Edge cases documented: daemon restart, pane missing, process exit, approval wait.

Tests:
- Unit tests for transition validator.

Scope:
- Implement forged-backed Subagent service APIs using existing SpawnAgent/SendInput/List/Get/Kill primitives.
- Add abstraction so subagent ops can run local or daemon-backed consistently.
- Implement operations: SpawnSubagent, SendMessage, WaitState, InterruptSubagent, KillSubagent, ListSubagents, GetSubagent.
- Store each operation in subagent_events.
- Normalize transport errors.

Acceptance:
- Service can manage multiple concurrent subagents.
- WaitState works for idle/working/approval/stopped with timeout.
- Failures emit structured events and retain debug context.

Tests:
- Unit tests with mocked forged client.
- Integration test with local forged daemon for spawn/send/wait/kill.

Scope:
- Implement harness capability registry:
  - supports_interactive_subagent
  - supports_reliable_idle_detection
  - supports_approval_signal
  - default_command_mode (interactive vs one-shot)
- Add guardrails:
  - reject continuous-subagent requests for one-shot command modes.
  - suggest fix (e.g., use interactive codex command, not codex exec).
- Expose capability info in subagent show/doctor output.

Acceptance:
- User cannot accidentally create "continuous" subagent on one-shot mode without explicit override.
- Messages clearly explain mismatch.

Tests:
- Unit tests for capability lookup and guards.

Scope:
- Implement revive workflow:
  - detect dead subagent (pane/process missing).
  - respawn compatible subagent.
  - inject revive preamble containing compact context (last task, summary, pending objective).
- Add revive policy flags:
  - never
  - ask
  - auto
- Ensure revive preserves parent linkage and audit trail.

Acceptance:
- Revive success path transparent to caller.
- Revive failure returns actionable remediation.

Tests:
- Integration tests for dead-subagent detection + respawn.

title: Epic: fmail TUI  Live Conversation Viewer
body:
A comprehensive TUI for watching fmail conversations in real-time and reviewing past activity. Built with Bubbletea/Lipgloss, integrating with forged for live streaming and the .fmail/ file store for historical data.

## Goals
- Real-time visibility into all agent-to-agent communication
- Historical replay and search across all messages
- Agent presence and activity monitoring
- Powerful filtering, search, and navigation
- Sequence diagram / timeline views for understanding coordination patterns
- Composing and sending messages directly from the TUI

## Phases
1. Foundation & Core Infrastructure (P0)
2. Core Views  Live Feed, Topics, Threads, Agents (P0-P1)
3. Power Features  Search, Timeline, Replay, Graph (P1-P2)
4. Operational Features  Compose, Bookmarks, Notifications (P2)
5. UX Polish  Keybindings, Layouts, Themes, Status Bar (P2-P3)

## Technical Notes
- Use Bubbletea (charmbracelet) for TUI framework, Lipgloss for styling
- Connect to forged via Unix socket (.fmail/forged.sock) or TCP (127.0.0.1:7463) for real-time
- Fall back to file-based polling (100ms) in standalone mode
- Message format: JSON files in .fmail/topics/<topic>/ and .fmail/dm/<agent>/
- Message IDs are sortable: YYYYMMDD-HHMMSS-NNNN
- Reply chains via reply_to field
- Agent registry in .fmail/agents/<name>.json
- Local TUI state (read markers, bookmarks, annotations) in .fmail/tui-state.json

title: fmail TUI: Bubbletea app scaffold and entry point
body:
Create the foundational Bubbletea application scaffold for the fmail TUI.

## Deliverables
- New package: `internal/fmailtui/` with app.go as the main model
- `cmd/fmail-tui/main.go` entry point (or integrate as `fmail tui` subcommand)
- Bubbletea Model/Init/Update/View lifecycle wired up
- Window size tracking (terminal resize handling)
- Basic view routing: an enum of viewIDs (dashboard, topics, thread, agents, search, timeline, etc.) with a view stack for push/pop navigation
- Keyboard event routing to the active view
- Global quit (q/Ctrl+C), help (?), and view-switch keybindings
- Accept CLI flags: --project (fmail project ID), --root (fmail root dir), --forged-addr (socket/TCP address), --theme (default/high-contrast), --poll-interval
- Initialize fmail store (internal/fmail.Store) and optionally connect to forged

## Technical Notes
- Follow the pattern in internal/tui/app.go but keep it much leaner
- Use a viewStack []viewID for breadcrumb-style navigation (push on enter, pop on Esc/backspace)
- Each view is a sub-model implementing its own Update/View
- Global keybindings handled before delegating to active view
- The model should hold references to shared state: fmail.Store, forgedClient (nullable), theme/styles, terminal dimensions

title: fmail TUI: Message data layer and store abstraction
body:
Build the data layer that the TUI uses to read messages, agents, and topics from both the fmail file store and the forged daemon.

## Deliverables
- `internal/fmailtui/data/provider.go`  interface abstracting message access:
  ```go
  type MessageProvider interface {
      // List topics with metadata (message count, last activity, participants)
      Topics() ([]TopicInfo, error)
      // List messages in a topic, with optional filters (since, from, priority, tags)
      Messages(topic string, opts MessageFilter) ([]fmail.Message, error)
      // List DM conversations for a given agent
      DMConversations(agent string) ([]DMConversation, error)
      // List DMs with a specific agent
      DMs(agent string, opts MessageFilter) ([]fmail.Message, error)
      // List all known agents
      Agents() ([]fmail.AgentRecord, error)
      // Search across all messages
      Search(query SearchQuery) ([]SearchResult, error)
      // Subscribe to new messages (returns a channel)
      Subscribe(filter SubscriptionFilter) (<-chan fmail.Message, func())
  }
  ```
- `FileProvider`  implementation backed by .fmail/ directory reads
  - Scans topics/ and dm/ directories
  - Parses JSON message files
  - Caches results with TTL (configurable, default 500ms)
  - File-based polling for Subscribe() at configurable interval
- `ForgedProvider`  implementation backed by forged socket connection
  - Connects via Unix socket or TCP
  - Uses the line-delimited JSON protocol (cmd: watch, send, etc.)
  - Real-time Subscribe() via watch stream
  - Falls back to FileProvider if connection lost
- `HybridProvider`  wraps both, prefers forged for live data, file store for historical queries
  - Auto-detects forged availability (check for .fmail/forged.sock)
  - Transparent fallback with reconnect attempts
- TopicInfo struct: Name, MessageCount, LastActivity time.Time, Participants []string, LastMessage *fmail.Message
- DMConversation struct: Agent string, MessageCount int, LastActivity time.Time, UnreadCount int
- SearchQuery struct: Text string, From string, To string, Priority string, Tags []string, Since/Until time.Time
- SearchResult struct: Message fmail.Message, Topic string, MatchOffset int, MatchLength int

## Technical Notes
- Message IDs are sortable (YYYYMMDD-HHMMSS-NNNN)  use this for efficient range queries
- For file-based scanning, use os.ReadDir and sort by filename (=chronological order)
- Keep an in-memory message cache with LRU eviction to avoid re-reading files
- The Subscribe channel should deliver messages in order, buffering if consumer is slow
- Forged protocol: send {"cmd":"watch","topic":"*","agent":"tui-viewer"} for all-topics stream

title: fmail TUI: Styling system and agent color assignment
body:
Build the theming/styling layer for the fmail TUI, including deterministic per-agent color assignment.

## Deliverables
- `internal/fmailtui/styles/theme.go`  Theme struct with all styled components:
  - Base colors: background, foreground, muted, accent, border
  - Message colors: own-message, other-message, system-message
  - Priority colors: high (red/bold), normal (default), low (dim)
  - Status colors: online (green), recent (yellow), stale (dim/grey)
  - UI chrome: header, footer, breadcrumb, selected-item, scrollbar
  - Borders: active-pane, inactive-pane, divider
- `styles/palette_default.go` and `styles/palette_high_contrast.go`  two theme palettes
- `styles/agent_colors.go`  deterministic agent color assignment:
  - Hash agent name to a color from a curated palette of 12-16 distinguishable terminal colors
  - Same agent always gets the same color across all views
  - Colors should be ANSI 256-compatible for wide terminal support
  - Provide both foreground and background variants
  - Cache computed colors in a map[string]lipgloss.Style
- `styles/message.go`  pre-built lipgloss styles for message rendering:
  - Message header (agent name in their color + timestamp)
  - Message body (with proper wrapping)
  - Reply indicator (indented with vertical bar)
  - Priority badge ([HIGH], [LOW])
  - Tag pills ([tag1] [tag2])
  - Unread indicator (bold/dot)
- `styles/layout.go`  layout helpers:
  - Responsive column widths based on terminal width
  - Consistent padding/margin constants
  - Panel border styles (focused vs unfocused)

## Technical Notes
- Use lipgloss from charmbracelet (already a dependency)
- Agent color hash: fnv32a(agentName) % len(colorPalette)  simple and deterministic
- Color palette should avoid red (reserved for high priority) and green (reserved for online status)
- Ensure all text has sufficient contrast in both default and high-contrast themes
- Follow existing patterns in internal/tui/styles/ but keep independent

title: fmail TUI: Local state persistence (read markers, bookmarks, settings)
body:
Implement local TUI state that persists across sessions, stored in .fmail/tui-state.json.

## Deliverables
- `internal/fmailtui/state/state.go`  TUIState struct and persistence:
  ```go
  type TUIState struct {
      ReadMarkers   map[string]string          // topic/dm -> last-read message ID
      Bookmarks     []Bookmark                  // saved message references
      Annotations   map[string]string           // message ID -> user annotation text
      StarredTopics []string                    // pinned/starred topic names
      SavedSearches []SavedSearch               // named search presets
      Preferences   Preferences                 // UI preferences
      NotifyRules   []NotificationRule          // notification configuration
      LastView      string                      // last active view (for session restore)
      LastTopic     string                      // last viewed topic
  }
  
  type Bookmark struct {
      MessageID string
      Topic     string    // topic name or "@agent" for DMs
      Note      string    // optional user note
      CreatedAt time.Time
  }
  
  type SavedSearch struct {
      Name   string
      Query  SearchQuery
  }
  
  type Preferences struct {
      DefaultLayout string   // "single", "split", "dashboard", "zen"
      LiveTailAuto  bool     // auto-scroll in live tail mode
      RelativeTime  bool     // show "2m ago" vs full timestamp
      SoundAlerts   bool     // terminal bell on notifications
  }
  
  type NotificationRule struct {
      Name     string
      Topic    string   // topic filter (glob pattern)
      From     string   // agent filter (glob pattern)
      Priority string   // min priority (high, normal, low)
      Tags     []string // required tags
      Enabled  bool
  }
  ```
- Load on startup, save on change (debounced writes, max 1 write/sec)
- File locking for concurrent access (in case multiple TUI instances)
- Migration support: version field in JSON, upgrade logic for schema changes
- Unread count computation: compare ReadMarkers against actual message IDs

## Technical Notes
- Store at .fmail/tui-state.json (not in topics/ or dm/ to avoid polluting message dirs)
- Use atomic write (write to .tmp, rename) to avoid corruption
- ReadMarkers use the last-read message ID  since IDs are sortable, any message with ID > marker is unread
- Keep file small: prune bookmarks older than 30 days on save, limit to 500 bookmarks
- This is purely local state  never synced via forged or across hosts

title: fmail TUI: Thread reconstruction engine (reply_to chain building)
body:
Build a thread reconstruction engine that assembles flat messages into threaded conversations using the reply_to field.

## Deliverables
- `internal/fmailtui/threading/threading.go`:
  ```go
  type Thread struct {
      Root     *fmail.Message   // first message (or the one with no reply_to in the chain)
      Messages []*ThreadNode    // all messages in chronological order
      Depth    int              // max nesting depth
      Agents   []string         // unique participating agents
      LastActivity time.Time    // most recent message timestamp
  }
  
  type ThreadNode struct {
      Message  *fmail.Message
      Parent   *ThreadNode      // nil if root
      Children []*ThreadNode    // replies to this message
      Depth    int              // nesting level (0 = root)
  }
  
  // BuildThreads takes a flat list of messages and returns threaded conversations
  func BuildThreads(messages []fmail.Message) []*Thread
  
  // BuildThread reconstructs a single thread from a root message ID
  func BuildThread(messages []fmail.Message, rootID string) *Thread
  
  // FlattenThread returns messages in display order (depth-first, chronological siblings)
  func FlattenThread(thread *Thread) []*ThreadNode
  ```
- Thread building algorithm:
  1. Index all messages by ID in a map
  2. For each message with reply_to, link to parent
  3. Messages with no reply_to (or reply_to not found) become thread roots
  4. Sort roots by earliest message timestamp
  5. Sort children within each parent by timestamp
  6. Handle orphaned replies gracefully (reply_to points to unknown ID  treat as new root)
  7. Handle cross-topic replies (reply_to from a different topic  show with a "from topic X" indicator)
- Thread summary generation: first line of root message + participant count + message count + last activity

## Technical Notes
- Many messages will have no reply_to (standalone messages)  each becomes a single-message thread
- Thread depth should be capped at a display limit (e.g., 10 levels) to prevent pathological nesting
- This is a pure data transformation  no I/O, no state, fully testable
- Write comprehensive tests with edge cases: circular reply_to, self-reply, missing parent, deep chains
- Performance target: reconstruct threads for 10,000 messages in <100ms

title: fmail TUI: Live Dashboard view (home screen)
body:
Build the main dashboard view  the home screen users see when launching the TUI.

## Layout (responsive to terminal width)
```

  AGENTS (4 online)            LIVE FEED                
   architect  "designing"     15:30 architect  task   
   coder-1    "JWT auth"        implement JWT auth     
   reviewer   (3m ago)        15:31 coder-1  task     
   tester     (2h ago)          on it, ETA 30min       
                               15:32 architect  build   
  TOPICS (hot)                   run full test suite     
   task       12 msgs/5m     15:33 coder-1  @arch    
   build      3 msgs/5m       need clarification on   
   editing    idle             token refresh flow      
   deploy     idle           15:34 architect  @coder  
                                 use sliding window...   
                                                         

 [T]opics [A]gents [/]Search [L]ive tail  [?]Help  q Quit
```

## Deliverables
- Left panel  Agent roster (compact):
  - Show all agents sorted by last_seen (most recent first)
  - Presence indicators:  online (<1m),  recent (<10m),  stale (>10m)
  - Status message truncated to fit column width
  - Agent name in their assigned color
  - Click/Enter to jump to Agent Detail view
- Left panel  Topic summary (below agents):
  - List topics sorted by recent activity
  - Activity bar: visual indicator of messages in last 5 minutes (miniature bar chart using block chars )
  - Show message count in time window
  - Click/Enter to jump to Topic view
- Right panel  Live message feed:
  - Real-time stream of ALL messages across all topics and DMs
  - Each message: timestamp, sender (colored)  target, first line of body
  - Auto-scrolls to bottom as new messages arrive
  - Scroll up to pause auto-scroll, press End/G to resume
  - Messages truncated to single line with "..." for long bodies
  - Click/Enter on a message to jump to its thread in the Thread View
- Header bar: "fmail TUI" + connection status (connected/polling/disconnected) + project name
- Footer bar: keybinding hints for navigation
- Auto-refresh: agent list and topic summary refresh on new messages or every 2s

## Technical Notes
- Use lipgloss.JoinHorizontal for the two-panel layout
- Left panel width: 30-40% of terminal, min 30 chars, max 50 chars
- The live feed should use the Subscribe() channel from the data provider
- Buffer up to 500 messages in the feed (drop oldest when full)
- On narrow terminals (<80 cols), collapse to single-panel mode (feed only)

title: fmail TUI: Topic Browser view
body:
Build the Topic Browser  a navigable list of all topics with preview pane.

## Layout
```

   build         23   5m ago        coder-1, tester

  Use sliding window     need clarification on           
  for token refresh.     token refresh flow              
  Reply in 30min.

  15:32 architect        on it, ETA 30min                
  run full test suite                                    

 Enter: open   star  d: DMs   navigate  / filter  Esc back
```

## Deliverables
- Topic list (top/left pane):
  - Sortable columns: topic name, message count, last active, participants
  - Default sort: last active (most recent first)
  - Cycle sort with `s` key (name  count  activity  participants)
  - Starred/pinned topics always at top (persisted in tui-state.json)
  - Star/unstar with `` or `*` key
  - Color-coded activity heat: hot (red/orange for active), warm (yellow), cold (grey for idle)
  - Activity thresholds configurable but defaults: hot=<5m, warm=<1h, cold=>1h
  - Fuzzy filter: typing in the filter box narrows the list instantly
  - Show total unread count per topic (from ReadMarkers in tui-state)
  - Unread topics shown in bold
- Preview pane (bottom/right):
  - Shows last N messages (default 10) from the selected topic
  - Messages rendered with agent colors and timestamps
  - Preview updates as cursor moves through topic list
  - Scrollable within the preview pane
- Navigation:
  - Enter on a topic  push to Thread View for that topic
  - `d`  switch to DM browser (similar layout but for direct messages)
  - `n`  compose new message to this topic
  - Esc  back to dashboard
- DM Browser (toggled with `d`):
  - Same layout but shows DM conversations instead of topics
  - Grouped by conversation partner
  - Show unread count per conversation
  - Enter  open DM thread

## Technical Notes
- Use the data provider's Topics() method, refresh on a timer (2s) or on new message events
- Fuzzy filtering: simple substring match is fine for V1, upgrade to fuzzy scoring later
- Preview pane reads messages lazily  only fetch when topic is highlighted
- Cache preview messages to avoid re-reading when navigating back
- Topic metadata (message count, participants) computed from message scan or cached

title: fmail TUI: Conversation Thread view
body:
Build the Thread View  the primary view for reading messages within a topic or DM conversation.

## Layout
```
 task  47 messages 
                                                          
   architect (15:30)  
   implement JWT auth for the user service.             
   Requirements: RS256 signing, 15min expiry,           
   refresh tokens with sliding window.                  
   Priority: high  Tags: [auth] [urgent]                
  
     coder-1 (15:31)  
     on it, ETA 30min. Quick question  should          
     refresh tokens be single-use or reusable?          
    
       architect (15:34)  
         Single-use. Each refresh mints a new           
         refresh token alongside the access token.      
        
                                                          
   tester (15:45)  
   Integration test suite is ready. Run with:           
   `go test ./auth/... -tags=integration`               
  
                                                          

 r reply  b bookmark  / search  j/k scroll  g/G top/bot  Esc back
```

## Deliverables
- Threaded message display:
  - Uses the thread reconstruction engine to group messages into threads
  - Thread roots displayed at base indentation
  - Replies indented with tree connectors (, , )
  - Max visible indent depth: 6 levels (deeper threads flatten with a "..." indicator)
  - Each message card shows:
    - Header: agent name (in their color) + timestamp (relative by default, full on focus)
    - Body: full message text with word wrapping
    - Footer (if applicable): priority badge, tag pills, reply-to indicator
    - Unread indicator: bold left border or dot for messages newer than ReadMarker
  - Empty lines between thread groups for visual separation
- Message selection:
  - j/k or / to move between messages
  - Selected message highlighted with accent border
  - Enter on a message  expand/collapse its children (if threaded)
  - Full message details on focus (show full timestamp, message ID, host)
- Message body rendering:
  - Wrap to pane width
  - Preserve code blocks (``` fenced) with syntax-highlighted background
  - Inline code (`backtick`) with distinct background
  - Truncate extremely long messages (>50 lines) with "... [show more]"  Enter to expand
- Scroll behavior:
  - j/k message-by-message, Ctrl+D/Ctrl+U half-page, g/G top/bottom
  - Scroll position remembered when navigating away and back
  - "New messages" indicator at bottom when scrolled up and new messages arrive
  - Jump to newest with G or clicking the indicator
- Flat mode toggle:
  - Press `f` to toggle between threaded and flat (chronological) view
  - Flat view shows all messages in time order without indentation
  - Useful when threads are sparse or reply_to is rarely used
- Header bar: topic name + message count + participant count
- Mark-as-read: automatically advance ReadMarker as user scrolls through messages

## Technical Notes
- Thread view is the most important view  invest heavily in rendering quality
- Use the threading.FlattenThread() to get display order
- Message cards should be lipgloss-styled boxes with agent-colored left border
- For performance, virtualize the list  only render visible messages + buffer
  (Bubbletea viewport or custom scroll implementation)
- Re-render only on: new message, scroll, resize, or selection change
- If the topic has >1000 messages, paginate (load 100 at a time, fetch more on scroll-up)

- Agent detail (bottom pane, shows for selected agent):
  - Full agent record: name, host, first_seen, last_seen, status
  - Activity sparkline: message frequency over the last N hours using braille/block characters
    - Each column = 15 min bucket, height = message count in that bucket

- Agent data comes from .fmail/agents/*.json (via data provider)

- Activity sparkline: use rune characters  for 8 levels of height
